sources.title: Articles on Smashing Magazine — For Web Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Adrian Bece)
articles.description: The View Transitions API is a new — but game-changing — feature that allows us to do the types of reactive state-based UI and page transitions that have traditionally been exclusive to JavaScript frameworks. In the second half of this mini two-part series, Adrian Bece expands on the demos from the first article to demonstrate how the View Transitions API can be used to transition not just elements between two states but the transition between full views and pages in single-page and multi-page applications.
articles.title: The View Transitions API And Delightful UI Animations (Part 2)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Let’s start into the new year with a little inspiration boost: wallpapers created with love by the community for the community. Happy 2024!
articles.title: The Magic Of New Beginnings (January 2024 Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Juan Diego Rodríguez)
articles.description: JavaScript may be the most popular client-side language in the world, but it’s far from perfect and not without its quirks. Juan Diego Rodriguez examines several “absurd” JavaScript eccentricities and explains how they made it into the language as well as how to avoid them in your own code.
articles.title: Making Sense Of “Senseless” JavaScript Features

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Adrian Bece)
articles.description: The View Transitions API is a new — but game-changing — feature that allows us to do the types of reactive state-based UI and page transitions that have traditionally been exclusive to JavaScript frameworks. In the first part of this mini two-part series, Adrian Bece thoroughly explains why we need the API and demonstrates its basic usage.
articles.title: The View Transitions API And Delightful UI Animations (Part 1)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Šime Vidas)
articles.description: Since the introduction of CSS viewport units in 2012, many of us have been using `width: 100vw` as a way to set an element’s width to the full width of the viewport. But, as Šime Vidas explains in this deep dive, `100vw` does not always represent the full width of the viewport due to differences in how browsers handle scrollbars.
articles.title: New CSS Viewport Units Do Not Solve The Classic Scrollbar Problem

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Luis Ouriach)
articles.description: Part 2 concentrates on the key points from Luis’ framework and practical tips about managing a design system that should be both robust and easy to adopt.
articles.title: Building Components For Consumption, Not Complexity (Part 2)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Brecht De Ruyte)
articles.description: Have you run into a situation where you need the padding of one element to align with the padding of another element? In this article, Brecht De Ruyte demonstrates the issue with a full-width slider component that breaks out of the main page container and shares a couple of techniques to keep it visually aligned with other elements on the page.
articles.title: CSS Scroll Snapping Aligned With Global Page Layout: A Full-Width Slider Case Study

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Luis Ouriach)
articles.description: Design systems can be of immense help, but failure to adopt them invalidates the hard work that goes into building the thing in the first place! In this two-part series of articles, Luis shares his experience with design systems and how you can overcome the potential pitfalls.
articles.title: Building Components For Consumption, Not Complexity (Part 1)

articles.author: Ankur Tyagi
articles.description: Welcome to this comprehensive guide to learning React. If you're looking for an efficient and well-thought-out approach to understanding React fundamentals, you've just hit the jackpot. This guide follows the 80/20 rule – we'll focus on a few key React concepts that you'll use in the majority of your work
articles.title: Learn React – A Guide to the Key Concepts

articles.author: Benedicta Onyebuchi
articles.description: As beginners, managing state in React applications can be challenging, especially when passing and utilizing props in deeply nested components.  The usual way of passing information from a main component to its smaller parts — like a parent passing data to a child, then to a grandchild — can
articles.title: How to Use React Context in Your Project – Beginner's Guide

articles.author: Benjamin Semah
articles.description: Template literals are a feature in JavaScript that were introduced with ES6. They gives you a more flexible and maintainable way of working with strings in JavaScript. By the end of this article, you will know how to use template literals. You will learn the syntax, the benefits, and some
articles.title: How to Use Template Literals in JavaScript

articles.author: Eivind Kjosbakken
articles.description: OCR is a valuable tool that you can use to extract text from images. But the OCR you are using may not work as intended for your specific needs. In such situations, fine-tuning your OCR engine is the way to go.  In this tutorial, I will show you how
articles.title: How to Fine-Tune EasyOCR with a Synthetic Dataset

articles.author: Samuel A. Olubiyo
articles.description: Microsoft Excel is a very powerful tool that you can use to analyze and visualize data.  In this tutorial, you will learn how to build a simple Excel Dashboard that visualizes important data from a large dataset.  The dataset we'll be working with is the transaction records of
articles.title: How to Analyze and Visualize Large Datasets with Microsoft Excel Using Pivot Tables and Charts

articles.author: Hamdaan Ali
articles.description: Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF) has been a consistent issue in application security and is among the OWASP Top 10 vulnerabilities.  In this walkthrough, you'll first learn what Server-Side Request Forgery is and how it differs from Client-Side Request Forgery. We will create a sample application to gain a better
articles.title: How to Defend Against Server-Side Request Forgery

articles.author: Joan Ayebola
articles.description: Strings, in the context of JavaScript, are essential data types that represent sequences of characters. They are integral to web development, forming the foundation for handling and presenting textual information on websites. Whether it's displaying user names, handling form input, or generating dynamic content, strings are omnipresent in JavaScript programming.
articles.title: The JavaScript String Handbook – How to Work with Strings in JS

articles.author: Saheed Azeez
articles.description: Imagine that you took a test in school, and you expected to score 80-90% based on how you thought you performed. But when the results came out, you learned that you scored 50-60% in the test. You'd be shocked, right?  Well sometimes these same scenarios play out in machine
articles.title: How to Build Machine Learning Models with Reliable Validation Scores

articles.author: Faith Oyama
articles.description: Imagine you're running a bustling restaurant. Orders fly in, dishes need cooking, tables require clearing, and happy customers demand attention. How can you handle all this chaos without everything turning into a total disaster? This is where concurrency comes in. In the world of server-side development, things can get just
articles.title: Concurrency in Kotlin Server-Side Development

articles.author: Manish Shivanandhan
articles.description: K-means clustering is a powerful technique that can help you discover hidden patterns and groupings in your datasets. Let’s look at how it works. K-means clustering is a basic but powerful tool in data science. It has changed the way we look at and understand large datasets. In this article,
articles.title: K-Means Clustering – How to Unveil Hidden Patterns in Your Data
